entry.title: Pelican Quickstart: Install Pelican on Ubuntu 16.04
entry.content:
Verified with: Ubuntu 16.04, Python 2.7.12, Pelican v-3.7.1

A static website generator uses a markup language, such as Markdown or reStructuredText, and a templating engine such as Jinja, to produce HTML files. Static sites can be hosted easily on github pages, Amazon S3 and even dropbox. Static site generators offer a lot of control over a web site through templates and plugins without the complexity dealing with a hosting provider or Content Management System (CMS).

Static sites are also more secure because there are fewer moving parts in the deployed website.

I chose Pelican as a static site generator based on its support for Markdown, Pygments, a large number of themes and plugins and of course being hackable in Python.

Why Choose a Static Site Generator?

The typical CMS driven website works by building each page on-demand, fetching content from a database and running it through a template engine. This means each page is assembled from templates and content on each request to the server.

A Static Site Generator takes a different approach and generate all the pages of the website only when there’s actually changes to the site. This means there’s no moving parts in the deployed website. Caching gets much easier, performance goes up and static sites are far more secure.

Install Virtualenv and Virtualenvwrapper

Virtualenv is a tool for creating Python environments isolated from the global Python installation and other virtualenv environments. Virtualenv makes it easier to work on multiple projects without introducing conflicts in dependencies or breaking system-wide packages.

Virtualenvwrapper provides a set of commands which simplifies working with virtual environments. It also places all your virtual environments in one place.

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get upgrade

sudo apt-get install wget curl git unzip
sudo apt-get install python-pip
sudo -H pip install --upgrade pip
pip install --user virtualenv
pip install --user virtualenvwrapper

cd
echo '#' >> ~/.bashrc
echo '# virtualenvwrapper setup' >> ~/.bashrc
echo 'export WORKON_HOME=$HOME/.virtualenv' >> ~/.bashrc
echo 'export PROJECT_HOME=$HOME/virtenv-projects' >> ~/.bashrc
echo 'source $HOME/.local/bin/virtualenvwrapper.sh' >> ~/.bashrc

source ~/.bashrc
mkdir $PROJECT_HOME

Install Pelican

Create a virtual environment to isolate the pelican package and its dependencies.

The mkproject myproject command creates the virtual environment in the $WORKON_HOME, and a project directory in $PROJECT_HOME. The workon myproject command will automatically cd to the project directory.

mkproject pelican
workon pelican

Install pelican in the virtualenv. If you plan on using Markdown as a markup format, you’ll need to also install the Markdown library.

pip install pelican
pip install --upgrade pelican
pip install Markdown typogrify

Add support for blogging with Jupyter/IPython Notebooks using the pelican-ipynb plugin (pelican-ipynb).

pip install jupyter ipython nbconvert beautifulsoup4

It’s a good idea to “freeze” the current state of the environment packages for future reference. To do this, run:

pip freeze > requirements.txt

Install Pelican Themes and Plugins

Pelican comes with no plugins and two very basic themes, so you have to clone the needed ones to a local directory. Here I clone the whole official plugins and themes repositories, allowing me to experiment with different options.

Themes and plugins can be cloned directly into the themes and plugins subdirectories of the Pelican site-packages (e.g. $WORKON_HOME/pelican/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pelican/). Instead I clone them to my home directory, so will need to specify the location in the pelican configuration file later.

git clone --recursive https://github.com/getpelican/pelican-themes ~/pelican-themes

git clone --recursive https://github.com/getpelican/pelican-plugins ~/pelican-plugins

Test it out

At this point you’re ready to create a test blog. Run pelican-quickstart to start an sequence of interactive of questions that help with the initial configuration. For most of the questions, it’s okay to just hit Enterand accept the default value.

The ones you may want to modify iniitially include:

  • the title of the website
  • the author of the website
  • n for the URL prefix

  • the timezone

    pelican-quickstart

Customize the pelican config file (pelicanconf.py)

Settings are configured in the form of a Python module (a file). There is an example settings file available for reference.

ref: Pelican > Docs > Settings

Edit the file pelicanconf.py to specify a theme, activate plugins and tell pelican where to find plugins and themes:

THEME = '../../pelican-themes/pelican-bootstrap3'
JINJA_ENVIRONMENT = {'extensions': ['jinja2.ext.i18n']}
PLUGIN_PATHS = ["../../pelican-plugins/"]
MARKUP = ('md', 'ipynb')
PLUGINS = [ 'i18n_subsites', 'ipynb.markup']

References

Virtualenv Tutorial Part 2 (Simon On Software)

virtualenvwrapper

Pipenv & Virtual Environments

entry.title: Notes on Installing VirtualBox and Vagrant on Ubuntu 14.04
entry.content:
created: Fri Feb 26 20:36:23 EST 2016
updated: Fri Sep 8 13:00:43 EDT 2017

Tested on:

  • VirtualBox v5.0.14, Vagrant v1.8.1 on Ubuntu 14.04.4 LTS
  • VirtualBox v5.1.26, Vagrant v2.0.0 on Ubuntu 14.04.5 LTS

These are notes for how to install VirtualBox and Vagrant on Ubuntu.

Installing VirtualBox

VirtualBox is a tool that allows you to create virtual computers running their own operating system within which you can safely experiment without breaking your actual computer.

VirtualBox is free (as in beer) and open source, and you can find more information at VirtualBox.org.

Instructions for Installing VirtualBox on Debian-based Linux Distributions

1. Download VirtualBox

Here you will find links to VirtualBox binaries and its source code.

Add the following line to your /etc/apt/sources.list: 

deb http://download.virtualbox.org/virtualbox/debian yakkety contrib

Note: According to your distribution, replace yakkety by xenial, vivid, utopic, trusty, raring, quantal, precise, lucid, jessie, wheezy, or squeeze.

2. Add the security key

The Oracle public key for apt-secure can be downloaded here for Debian 8 (“Jessie”) / Ubuntu 16.04 (“Xenial”) and later. You can add these keys with:

sudo apt-key add oracle_vbox_2016.asc

or combine downloading and registering in a single step with:

wget -q https://www.virtualbox.org/download/oracle_vbox_2016.asc -O- | sudo apt-key add -

3. Install VirtualBox

To install VirtualBox, do:

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install virtualbox-5.1
sudo apt-get install dkms

Test it out:

vboxmanage --version
virtualbox

Install VirtualBox Guest Additions

Guest Additions is a package of software components that comes with VirtualBox to improve the Guest performance and provide additional convenience features.

Guest Additions are designed to be installed inside a virtual machine after the guest operating system has been installed. They consist of device drivers and system applications that optimize the guest operating system for better performance and usability.

The VirtualBox Guest Additions for all supported guest operating systems are provided as a single CD-ROM image file which is called VBoxGuestAdditions.iso. This image file is located in the installation directory of VirtualBox. To install the Guest Additions for a particular VM, you mount this ISO file in your VM as a virtual CD-ROM and install from there.

Detailed installation instructions can be found here:

Oracle VM VirtualBox User Manual - Chapter 4. Guest Additions

Installing the Guest Additions is quite simple, really. There’s nothing you have to download, as they come with your VirtualBox installation. All you need to do is boot up your desired virtual machine, and then choose Devices -> Insert Guest Additions CD image. This will insert an ISO image into the virtual CD drive attached to the virtual machine, which should start an autorun prompt.

In Windows, it should install with ease thanks to the installer. In Linux, you’ll need to enter your password before the installer takes care of the rest. However, it’ll only work well if you make sure you have gcc, g++, dkms, and kernel-devel installed.

In Ubuntu, before choosing to install the Guest Additions, you just need to run the terminal command:

sudo apt-get install gcc g++ dkms

VirtualBox’s Guest Additions: What They Are And How To Install Them

Upgrading VirtualBox Guest Additions

After upgrading VirtualBox it is recommended to upgrade the guest additions as well.

Each version of VirtualBox, even minor releases, ship with their own version of the Guest Additions. While the interfaces through which the VirtualBox core communicates with the Guest Additions are kept stable so that Guest Additions already installed in a VM should continue to work when VirtualBox is upgraded on the host, for best results, it is recommended to keep the Guest Additions at the same version.

Starting with VirtualBox 3.1, the Windows and Linux Guest Additions therefore check automatically whether they have to be updated. If the host is running a newer VirtualBox version than the Guest Additions, a notification with further instructions is displayed in the guest.

Chapter 4. Guest Additions - 4.1. Introduction

Keep Guest Additions Up to Date with the vagrant-vbguest Plugin

You can install a plugin called vagrant-vbguest which will check and update the VirtualBox guest additions every time you run a vagrant up command.

When we upgrade VirtualBox, we will get prompted to update the guest additions. That means that the installed version updates with the base version of VirtualBox itself. It does not automatically go back and retrofit the existing machines with the updated guest additions though.

If you run vagrant up after you’ve updated VirtualBox, you’ll see a message indicating you have a mismatch in your guest additions.

Keeping Guest Additions Up to Date with the vagrant-vbguest Plugin

there’s actually a nice & automated way of keeping your VM’s guest additions in sync with virtualbox.

Vagrant Tip: Sync VirtualBox Guest Additions

It’s not difficult to manually update the VirtualBox Guest Additions version, from the host command line:

vagrant vbguest

I have never realized how difficult it is to find the download page for the VirtualBox Guest additions, it is not accessible from the wiki, at this time… After some time spent on Google, here is the answer…

VirtualBox Guest Additions ISO Download

INSTALLING VAGRANT

Installing Vagrant is extremely easy. Head over to the Vagrant downloads page and get the appropriate installer or package for your platform. You can find the SHA256 checksums for Vagrant 2.0.0 online and you can verify the checksum’s signature file, which has been signed using HashiCorp’s GPG key.

Install the package using standard procedures for your operating system.

Caveats

Beware of system package managers! Some operating system distributions include a vagrant package in their upstream package repos. Please do not install Vagrant in this manner. Typically these packages are missing dependencies or include very outdated versions of Vagrant. If you install via your system’s package manager, it is very likely that you will experience issues. Please use the official installers on the downloads page.

Installing Vagrant

Vagrant version 2.0.0 was released September 7, 2017. CHANGELOG.md

wget https://releases.hashicorp.com/vagrant/2.0.0/vagrant_2.0.0_x86_64.deb
sudo dpkg -i vagrant_2.0.0_x86_64.deb 
apt-get install -f

Test it out:

which vagrant
vagrant --version
